snippet: Even as it stands a good chance to win a second seat in Parliament, the U.K. Independence Party has lost the support of its founder, who deplores it as xenophobic.
abstract: Britain's populist, anti-European Union Independence Party is poised to gain a second seat in Parliament; shift would send further shudders through governing Conservatives, who fear losing crucial support on nationalist right; party has nonetheless lost the support of founder Alan Sked, who has expressed disdain for its xenophobic anti-immigration focus.
lead_paragraph: Even as it stands a good chance to win a second seat in Parliament, the U.K. Independence Party has lost the support of its founder, who deplores it as xenophobic.

headline.main: Anti-E.U. Party in Britain Strives for Wider Clout
headline.print_headline: Anti-E.U. Party in Britain Strives for Wider Clout
